I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA)1 for the Integrated Strategy for 
Sustainable Land Management in Dryland Ecosystems.2 In February 2012, an ADB mission 
visited the PRC and reached an understanding with the government on the TA impact, outcome, 
outputs, cost estimates, financing plan, implementation arrangements, and consultants’ terms of 
reference. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  The  development  of  a  long-term  cooperation  framework  for  the  PRC–Global 
Environment Facility (GEF) Partnership on Land Degradation in Dryland Ecosystems (2003–
2012)  was  initiated  in  2002  by  the  PRC  government,  with  support  from  ADB,  GEF,  the 
International Fund for Agricultural Development, and the World Bank. The partnership promotes 
the adoption of an integrated ecosystem management approach to combating land degradation 
in the northwestern region of the PRC. The future development of the partnership beyond 2012 
was discussed during various consultation meetings in Beijing, PRC with national and provincial 
government agencies and international stakeholders. The TA report is prepared based on the 
results of the consultation meetings to develop a renewed partnership strategy for the following 
10 years. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The PRC suffers from some large-scale land degradation problems, such as severe 
wind  and  water  erosion,  soil  nutrient  losses,  waterlogging,  salinization,  river  system 
sedimentation, deforestation, grassland degradation, and biodiversity loss. The dryland areas of 
the western PRC, which cover about 40% of the country’s land area, contain some of the most 
severely degraded land in the world. With only about 7% of the world’s farmland and 6% of the 
world’s  annual  water  runoff,  the  PRC  must  feed  22%  of  the  world’s  population.  Land 
degradation, therefore, significantly threatens the lives of local residents, in particular, and the 
future economic welfare of the nation, in general. 
 
4.  The long-term framework for the partnership, updated in 2008, supports the national and 
local  governments’  pursuit  of  a  sustainable  environment  and  development  in  drylands. 
Sustainable land management (SLM) practices applied in the pilots and investment programs 
included reforestation, soil erosion control measures, greenhouses for vegetable production, 
mulching,  grazing  management,  and  irrigation  control.  These  practices  were  implemented 
alongside  rural  infrastructure,  rural  energy,  biogas,  solar  energy,  and  other  development 
activities that contributed to income generation and improved livelihoods in the pilot sites. These 
activities were supported by policy actions, legislation, thematic studies, capacity development, 
and knowledge management. The approach was institutionalized at the provincial level through 
mainstreaming strategies and an action plan to ensure investment and financial flows for SLM 
and livelihood activities. 
 
5.  Many technical and institutional aspects of the implementation and management of the 
partnership require further updating to meet the increasing demand for support and investments 
at the local levels to combat land degradation. The government and international partners have 
identified the following development issues that need to be addressed for the partnership to

successfully continue: (i) the need to focus on replication and up-scaling of the achievements of 
the partnership, with a strong emphasis on investments at the provincial level; (ii) the need to 
target capacity development and its linkage to demonstration and investment activities; (iii) the 
need  for  a  broader  financial  resource  mobilization  strategy,  taking  into  consideration 
government,  private  sector,  and  development  partner  resources,  as  well  as  innovative 
mechanisms such as eco-compensation programs; and (iv) the need for the program to have a 
stronger link with the PRC National Action Plan for the United Nations Convention to Combat 
Desertification  (UNCCD)  and  close  alignment  with  the  secretariat  of  the  PRC  National 
Committee for implementation of the UNCCD in the State Forestry Administration (SFA). 
 
6.  Building on the progress made by the partnership since 2002, the government requested 
TA support to prepare a new framework that will guide the implementation of future activities 
under the partnership. ADB has served as the lead GEF agency for the partnership since 2002 
and  has  provided  support  for  capacity  development  efforts  and  the  establishment  of 
coordination  mechanisms.  ADB’s  comparative  advantage  as  the  lead  GEF  agency  for  the 
partnership includes considerable experience with the identification, design, and implementation 
of TA and investment projects with the PRC as well as the ability to incorporate capacity 
development and TA into its projects. The government has also committed to allocating $4 
million  from  the  land  degradation  focal  area  of  its  GEF-53 resources  and  commensurate 
domestic funds to support the management and implementation of the renewed framework for 
SLM for dryland ecosystems.  
 
7.  The TA aims to promote inclusive growth and environmental sustainability, and supports 
ADB’s strategic priorities in its country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for the PRC.4 The TA 
also supports the PRC’s sustainable development agenda for a harmonious society, as outlined 
in the country's Twelfth Five-Year Plan (2011–2015). In line with ADB’s Strategy 2020, climate 
change and environmental sustainability are also key considerations of the TA design, including 
greater  preparedness  for  extreme  weather  events  and  conservation  of  water  and  natural 
resources. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact will be improved productivity and inclusive growth in dryland regions. The 
outcome will be a 10-year development strategy for SLM for dryland ecosystems endorsed by 
government. To attain the expected outcome, four outputs have been identified: (i) scope of 
partnership  development  strategy  (PDS)  identified,  (ii)  resource  mobilization  strategies  for 
implementation  of  national  and  provincial  programs  under  the  PDS,  (iii)  institutional 
arrangements enhanced for implementation of the PDS, and (iv) PDS prepared for the PRC—
GEF partnership on land degradation in dryland ecosystems for 2014–2023.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Scope  of  partnership  development  strategy  identified.  This  output 
involves carrying out an updated assessment of the current status of SLM in the PRC and future 
needs. The TA will support (i) the preparation of a review report on (a) the status and scope of 
land degradation; (b) likely climate change impacts; and (c) biodiversity, poverty, gender, and

3 
livelihood  issues  in  dryland  areas  in  the  PRC;  and  (ii)  based  on  the  review  outcome,  a 
consultative process to identify and confirm the additional target provinces and priority areas for 
the PDS for endorsement by central and provincial authorities.  
 
10.  Major activities for output 1 include the following: (i) review the results of phase 1 of the 
partnership, including establishment of baseline indicators for impact statement; (ii) conduct 
consultation and participatory meetings and workshops with national and provincial agencies 
and  development  partners;  (iii)  survey  the  knowledge,  attitudes,  and  practices  of  local 
stakeholders  to  prepare  a  behavior-change  communication  strategy  and  combine  with  the 
design of the PDS; (iv) identify priority provinces and project areas for the strategy and program; 
and (v) prepare a review report on scope of land degradation, biodiversity, poverty, gender, and 
livelihood issues in dryland ecosystems in the PRC and proposed strategy and program scope. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Resource  mobilization  strategies  endorsed  for  implementation  of 
national and provincial programs under the partnership development strategy. SLM, at a 
scale required in the PRC, will require significant financial resources beyond what national, 
provincial,  and  local  governments  can  provide.  The  TA  will  support  the  preparation  of  (i) 
resource mobilization strategies for accessing multiple funding sources prepared and endorsed 
at national and provincial levels, (ii) a strategy for public–private partnerships and payment for 
environmental services prepared and endorsed to support implementation of the PDS, and (iii) 
prefeasibility studies completed for at least two priority projects under two of the provincial 
Twelfth Five-Year Plans (still to be determined). 
 
12.  Major activities for output 2 include the following: (i) work with the provinces to undertake 
a process of criteria setting and prioritization for demonstration and investment projects and 
capacity support activities; (ii) support the evaluation of the costing of provincial IEM SAPs and 
priority projects under the Twelfth Five-Year Plan, and undertake consultations with central and 
provincial governments and development partners on financial resource mobilization; (iii) assess 
opportunities for payment for environmental services and eco-compensation approaches to be 
used and scaled up under the program; (iv) identify opportunities for public–private partnerships 
and prepare a private sector engagement strategy; (v) develop an overall financial resource 
mobilization strategy for the PDS and program, and design project and fund management 
models for the overall program and for priority projects; and (vi) identify a shortlist of high-priority 
investment projects and support prefeasibility assessments for at least two projects. 
 
13.  Output  3:  Institutional  arrangements  enhanced  for  implementation  of  the 
partnership development strategy. Effective coordination mechanisms have been promoted 
and established within the partnership, but there is a need to further institutionalize coordination 
and cooperation, especially at the national and interprovincial levels. Similarly, the large number 
of international organizations and national agencies involved in the partnership activities may 
pose some challenges in the coordination and effective management of the program. The TA 
will provide support to (i) strengthen the multisector and multilevel coordination framework for 
endorsement of the development strategy at the national and provincial levels, and (ii) integrate 
the  development  strategy  and  program  with  the  national  implementation  and  reporting 
requirements of the UNCCD. 
 
14.  Major activities for output 3 include the following: (i) assess current institutional and 
coordination arrangements under phase 1 of the partnership, the UNCCD and other relevant 
international conventions; (ii) discuss and agree upon enhanced institutional arrangements and

4 
coordination  mechanisms  under  the  PDS;  and  (iii)  prepare  final  recommendations  on  the 
enhanced multisector and multilevel coordination arrangements for the PDS. 
 
15.  Output 4: Partnership development strategy prepared for the People's Republic of 
China–Global  Environment  Facility  partnership  on  land  degradation  in  dryland 
ecosystems for 2014–2023. The findings and recommendations gathered during the TA will be 
summarized to form new strategic planning documents for the partnership including (i) the 
development strategy and program framework, with detailed results indicators agreed at the 
central  and  provincial  levels;  (ii)  a  draft  GEF  program  framework  document;  and  (iii)  a 
knowledge product that summarizes the strategic approach and policy recommendations in the 
PDS for public dissemination. 
 
16.  Major  activities  for  output  4  include  the  following:  (i)  design  a  results  framework, 
indicators, and monitoring and evaluation arrangements for the PDS and program; (ii) undertake 
participatory capacity needs assessment at central and provincial levels and prepare a targeted 
capacity strengthening program to be integrated within the PDS; (iii) prepare a GEF program 
framework  document  based  on  consultation  with  the  MOF,  SFA,  target  provinces,  GEF 
agencies and secretariat, and other stakeholders; and (iv) prepare for public dissemination a 
knowledge product that summarizes the strategic approach and policy recommendations in the 
PDS. 
 
17.  No major risks related to implementation of the TA have been identified. The strong 
leadership, vision, and ownership by the MOF and SFA, as demonstrated over the last 10 years 
of the partnership, will ensure that a relevant and pragmatic development strategy is prepared. 
One minor risk is that some sector agencies may lack incentives to actively participate in the 
discussions to develop a new multisector long-term strategy for the partnership. This risk will be 
overcome  through  the  conduct  of  extensive  consultations  and  planning  meetings  with  the 
involved stakeholders at the national, provincial, and local levels to ensure that all sectors are 
covered. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The proceeds of the 
TA will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The government will provide support in the form of 
counterpart staff and their travel and per diem, office facilities, meeting venues for workshop, 
and other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  Implementation of the TA will take 15 months from 1 October 2012 to 31 December 
2013. The MOF will be the executing agency for the TA and the SFA will be the implementing 
agency. The TA will make use of the comprehensive coordination structure established for the 
partnership since 2002 at both central and provincial levels.5 At the central level, a steering 
                                                
5  Institutional and organizational arrangements for the partnership were assessed during the preparation of TA 
completion report in 2010 for the TA 4358-PRC: Capacity Building to Combat Land Degradation. The assessment 
acknowledged the significant project management capacity of the executing and implementing agencies. Unlike 
previous GEF-supported grants, the recruitment of consultants for the proposed TA will be done by ADB, as 
requested by the SFA.

5 
committee has been established comprising representatives from the national legislative and 
concerned ministries and agencies. A central project coordination office is established at the 
MOF, headed by the director general of the Department of International Cooperation, while the 
central project management office (CPMO) established in the SFA is headed by the deputy 
director general of the Department of Science and Technology. Through the CPMO, the SFA 
will implement the TA and be responsible for day-to-day operational matters and implementation 
activities.  The  SFA  will  administer  the  training,  seminars,  and  conferences,  for  which  an 
advance payment facility will be established. The SFA has the capacity to manage the funds, as 
it has also implemented GEF grants. 
 
20.  The SFA will provide ADB with biannual progress reports during the implementation 
period, and a TA completion report within 3 months of the TA completion date. Provincial project 
coordination offices and provincial project management offices have already been set up in 
Gansu, Qinghai, and Shaanxi provinces, and in the Inner Mongolia, Ningxia Hui, and Xinjiang 
Uygur  autonomous  regions,  each  headed  by  the  vice-governor  or  chair  in  charge  of  the 
agriculture  sector. In  addition,  specialized  task forces  on  legal  and  policy,  institutions  and 
planning land degradation monitoring, and IEM have been established by the provinces to 
undertake project activities under the partnership. 
 
21.  The  SFA  will  be  supported  by  four  individual  consultants:  a  dryland  management 
specialist and team leader (international, 5 person-months), a sustainable land management 
specialist (national, 8 person-months), a financial specialist (national, 8 person-months), and a 
natural  resources  management  and  institutional  expert  (national,  6  person-months).  The 
consultants will be financed and engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) using the individual selection method. This 
method is considered appropriate and cost-effective given (i) the organizational structure has 
already  been  established  for  the  partnership,  and  (ii)  the  size  of  the  TA.  The  terms  and 
conditions of the technical assistance framework agreement executed between the government 
and ADB dated 23 December 1996 apply to the ADB-financed consultants. The outline terms of 
reference for the consultants are provided in Appendix 3. 
 
22.  The  TA  will  follow  the  standard  monitoring  and  supervision  procedures  for  ADB-
administered TA. Best practices and lessons learned will be disseminated through national and 
international workshops and through various technical reports, knowledge products, and other 
publications posted on the websites of the partnership (http://www.gefop12.cn) and of ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Integrated Strategy for Sustainable 
Land Management in Dryland Ecosystems, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Ministry of Finance (MOF), State Forestry Administration (SFA), and participating 
provinces will be supported by one international (5 person-months) and three national (22 
person-months) individual consultants.  
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
1.  Dryland Management Specialist and Team Leader (international, 5 person-
months) 
 
2.  The specialist will be responsible for the overall coordination and technical outputs of the 
technical assistance (TA). The specialist will review the contribution by the national experts and 
integrate the findings into the final outputs of the TA as defined in output 4. The specialist 
should have (i) a university degree in forestry, natural resources management, or agricultural 
science;  and (ii)  at  least  10  years  of  relevant  international  experience  in  sustainable  land 
management (SLM) in dryland areas, preferably including in the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC). Specific tasks will include the following: 
(i)  coordinate and review the technical work of the national consultants;  
(ii)  design  results  framework,  indicators  and  monitoring,  and  evaluation 
arrangements for the partnership development strategy (PDS) and program; 
(iii)  undertake  participatory  capacity  needs  assessment  at  central  and  provincial 
levels and prepare a targeted capacity strengthening program to be integrated 
within the PDS; 
(iv)  identify specific and targeted research needs to stimulate further innovations 
under the PDS and program;  
(v)  prepare the Global Environment Facility (GEF) program framework document 
based on consultation with the MOF, SFA, target provinces, GEF agencies and 
secretariat, and other stakeholders;  
(vi)  prepare  for  public  dissemination  a  knowledge  product  that  summarizes  the 
strategic approach and policy recommendations in the PDS; and 
(vii)  participate in and present findings at national and regional workshops. 
 
2.  Sustainable Land Management Specialist (national, 8 person-months) 
 
3.  The specialist will be responsible for output 1, and will closely work with the international 
team leader in preparing the final outputs of the TA. The specialist should have (i) a university 
degree in forestry, natural resources management, or agricultural science; and (ii) at least 8 
years of relevant experience in SLM in dryland areas. Specific tasks will include the following: 
(i)  review  on  the  results  of  phase  1  of  the  PRC–GEF  partnership,  including 
establishment of baseline indicators for impact statement; 
(ii)  conduct consultation and participatory meetings and workshops with national and 
provincial agencies and development partners; 
(iii)  conduct a knowledge, attitudes, and practices survey of local stakeholders to 
inform about the behavior-change communication strategy and the design of the 
PDS; 
(iv)  identify priority provinces and project areas for the strategy and program;

Appendix 3  11 
(v)  prepare  a  review  report  on  scope  of  land  degradation,  biodiversity,  poverty, 
gender, and livelihood issues in dryland ecosystems in the PRC and propose a 
strategy and program scope; 
(vi)  participate in and present findings at national and regional workshops; and 
(vii)  conduct any task that is reasonably requested by the team leader. 
 
3.  Financial Specialist (national, 8 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will be responsible for output 2, and will closely work with the international 
team leader in the delivery of the final outputs of the TA. The specialist should have (i) a 
university degree in public administration or any related field, and (ii) at least 8 years of relevant 
experience in project management and design. Specific tasks will include the following: 
(i)  work with the participating provinces to undertake the process of criteria setting 
and prioritization for demonstration and investment projects, financial implications 
and requirements, and capacity support activities; 
(ii)  identify  a  shortlist  of  high-priority  investment  projects  and  support  financial 
prefeasibility assessments for at least two projects; 
(iii)  participate in and present findings at national and regional workshops; and 
(iv)  conduct any task that is reasonably requested by the team leader. 
 
4.  Natural Resources Management and Institutional Expert (national, 6 person-
months) 
 
5.  The expert will be responsible for the activities under output 3, and will closely work with 
the international team leader in the delivery of the final outputs of the TA. The expert should 
have (i) a university degree in forestry, natural resources management, or agricultural science; 
and (ii) at least 8 years of relevant experience in institutional aspects of SLM in dryland areas. 
Specific tasks will include the following: 
(i)  assess current institutional and coordination arrangements under phase 1 of the 
partnership, the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification, and other 
relevant international conventions, 
(ii)  discuss and agree upon enhanced institutional arrangements and coordination 
mechanisms under the PDS, 
(iii)  prepare  a  report  on  the  enhanced  multisector  and  multilevel  coordination 
arrangements for the PDS, 
(iv)  participate in and present findings at national and regional workshops, and 
(v)  conduct any task that is reasonably requested by the team leader. 
 
6.  The consultants will submit their draft and final reports in English and Chinese language 
to the government and ADB, including one electronic copy on a CD-ROM. The reports will be 
published in Chinese and English language and made available online.
